running on every core. It increases the CPU time usage for timer ISRs
by N on an N-core system.
children.name: ESP_TIMER_ISR_AFFINITY
children.title: timer interrupt core affinity

children.help:
Allows using ESP_TIMER_ISR dispatch method (ESP_TIMER_TASK dispatch method is also avalible).
- ESP_TIMER_TASK - Timer callbacks are dispatched from a high-priority esp_timer task.
- ESP_TIMER_ISR - Timer callbacks are dispatched directly from the timer interrupt handler.
The ISR dispatch can be used, in some cases, when a callback is very simple
or need a lower-latency.
children.name: ESP_TIMER_SUPPORTS_ISR_DISPATCH_METHOD
children.title: Support ISR dispatch method

children.help: Number of volumes (logical drives) to use.
children.name: FATFS_VOLUME_COUNT
children.title: Number of volumes

children.help:
Support long filenames in FAT. Long filename data increases
memory usage. FATFS can be configured to store the buffer for
long filename data in stack or heap.
children.name: FATFS_LONG_FILENAMES
children.title: Long filename support

children.help: Specify the size of the sector in bytes for FATFS partition generator.
children.name: FATFS_SECTOR_SIZE
children.title: Sector size

children.help:
OEM code page used for file name encodings.

If "Dynamic" is selected, code page can be chosen at runtime using
f_setcp function. Note that choosing this option will increase
application size by ~480kB.
children.name: FATFS_CHOOSE_CODEPAGE
children.title: OEM Code Page

children.help: Maximum long filename length. Can be reduced to save RAM.
children.name: FATFS_MAX_LFN
children.title: Max long filename length

children.help:
Choose encoding for character and string arguments/returns when using
FATFS APIs. The encoding of arguments will usually depend on text
editor settings.
children.name: FATFS_API_ENCODING
children.title: API character encoding

children.help:
This option sets the FATFS configuration value _FS_LOCK.
The option _FS_LOCK switches file lock function to control duplicated file open
and illegal operation to open objects.

* 0: Disable file lock function. To avoid volume corruption, application
should avoid illegal open, remove and rename to the open objects.

* >0: Enable file lock function. The value defines how many files/sub-directories
can be opened simultaneously under file lock control.

Note that the file lock control is independent of re-entrancy.
children.name: FATFS_FS_LOCK
children.title: Number of simultaneously open files protected by lock function

children.help:
This option sets FATFS configuration value _FS_TIMEOUT, scaled to milliseconds.
Sets the number of milliseconds FATFS will wait to acquire a mutex when
operating on an open file. For example, if one task is performing a lengthy
operation, another task will wait for the first task to release the lock,
and time out after amount of time set by this option.
children.name: FATFS_TIMEOUT_MS
children.title: Timeout for acquiring a file lock, ms

children.help:
This option affects FATFS configuration value _FS_TINY.

If this option is set, _FS_TINY is 0, and each open file has its own cache,
size of the cache is equal to the _MAX_SS variable (512 or 4096 bytes).
This option uses more RAM if more than 1 file is open, but needs less reads
and writes to the storage for some operations.

If this option is not set, _FS_TINY is 1, and single cache is used for
all open files, size is also equal to _MAX_SS variable. This reduces the
amount of heap used when multiple files are open, but increases the number
of read and write operations which FATFS needs to make.
children.name: FATFS_PER_FILE_CACHE
children.title: Use separate cache for each file

children.help:
When the option is enabled, internal buffers used by FATFS will be allocated
from external RAM. If the allocation from external RAM fails, the buffer will
be allocated from the internal RAM.
Disable this option if optimizing for performance. Enable this option if
optimizing for internal memory size.
children.name: FATFS_ALLOC_PREFER_EXTRAM
children.title: Prefer external RAM when allocating FATFS buffers

children.help:
The fast seek feature enables fast backward/long seek operations without
FAT access by using an in-memory CLMT (cluster link map table).
Please note, fast-seek is only allowed for read-mode files, if a
file is opened in write-mode, the seek mechanism will automatically fallback
to the default implementation.
children.name: FATFS_USE_FASTSEEK
children.title: Enable fast seek algorithm when using lseek function through VFS FAT

children.help:
These are specialized alternatives to stdio functions for working
directly with FATFS without VFS.  Legacy code may need functions,
but for new development, it is advised to use stdio under VFS.

0: Disable. FF_PRINT_LLI, FF_PRINT_FLOAT and FF_STRF_ENCODE have no effect.
1: Enable without LF-CRLF conversion.
2: Enable with LF-CRLF conversion.
children.name: FATFS_USE_STRFUNC_CHOICE
children.title: Enable string functions, f_gets(), f_putc(), f_puts() and f_printf()

children.name: FATFS_PRINT_LLI
children.title: Make fatfs f_printf() support long long argument

children.name: FATFS_PRINT_FLOAT
children.title: Make fatfs f_printf() support floating point argument

children.help:
When FF_LFN_UNICODE >= 1 with LFN enabled, string functions convert the character
encoding in it. FF_STRF_ENCODE selects assumption of character encoding ON THE FILE
to be read/written via those functions.
0: ANSI/OEM in current CP
1: Unicode in UTF-16LE
2: Unicode in UTF-16BE
3: Unicode in UTF-8
children.name: FATFS_STRF_ENCODE_CHOICE
children.title: FatFS string functions: convert character encoding

children.help:
If fast seek algorithm is enabled, this defines the size of
CLMT buffer used by this algorithm in 32-bit word units.
This value should be chosen based on prior knowledge of
maximum elements of each file entry would store.
children.name: FATFS_FAST_SEEK_BUFFER_SIZE
children.title: Fast seek CLMT buffer size

children.help:
If set to 0, the 'newlib' library's default size (BLKSIZ) is used (128 B).
If set to a non-zero value, the value is used as the block size.
Default file buffer size is set to this value
and the buffer is allocated when first attempt of reading/writing to a file is made.
Increasing this value improves fread() speed, however the heap usage is increased as well.

NOTE: The block size value is shared by all the filesystem functions
accessing target media for given file descriptor!
See 'Improving I/O performance' section of 'Maximizing Execution Speed' documentation page
for more details.
children.name: FATFS_VFS_FSTAT_BLKSIZE
children.title: Default block size

children.help:
Enables automatic calling of f_sync() to flush recent file changes after each call of vfs_fat_write(),
vfs_fat_pwrite(), vfs_fat_link(), vfs_fat_truncate() and vfs_fat_ftruncate() functions.
This feature improves file-consistency and size reporting accuracy for the FatFS,
at a price on decreased performance due to frequent disk operations
children.name: FATFS_IMMEDIATE_FSYNC
children.title: Enable automatic f_sync

children.help: Allows FATFS volume label to be specified using f_setlabel
children.name: FATFS_USE_LABEL
children.title: Use FATFS volume label

children.help:
If enabled, the whole link operation (including file copying) is performed under lock.
This ensures that the link operation is atomic, but may cause performance for large files.
It may create less fragmented file copy.
children.name: FATFS_LINK_LOCK
children.title: Perform the whole link operation under lock

children.help:
If enabled, the buffers used by FATFS will be allocated separately from the rest of the structure.
This option is useful when using multiple FATFS instances with different
sector sizes, as the buffers will be allocated according to the sector size.
If disabled, the greatest sector size will be used for all FATFS instances.
(In most cases, this would be the sector size of Wear Levelling library)
This might cause more memory to be used than necessary.
children.name: FATFS_USE_DYN_BUFFERS
children.title: Use dynamic buffers

children.help:
Amazon has released an SMP version of the FreeRTOS Kernel which can be found via the following link:
https://github.com/FreeRTOS/FreeRTOS-Kernel/tree/smp

IDF has added an experimental port of this SMP kernel located in
components/freertos/FreeRTOS-Kernel-SMP. Enabling this option will cause IDF to use the Amazon SMP
kernel. Note that THIS FEATURE IS UNDER ACTIVE DEVELOPMENT, users use this at their own risk.

Leaving this option disabled will mean the IDF FreeRTOS kernel is used instead, which is located in:
components/freertos/FreeRTOS-Kernel. Both kernel versions are SMP capable, but differ in
their implementation and features.
children.name: FREERTOS_SMP
children.title: Run the Amazon SMP FreeRTOS kernel instead (FEATURE UNDER DEVELOPMENT)

children.help:
This version of FreeRTOS normally takes control of all cores of the CPU. Select this if you only want
to start it on the first core. This is needed when e.g. another process needs complete control over the
second core.
children.name: FREERTOS_UNICORE
children.title: Run FreeRTOS only on first core

children.help:
Sets the FreeRTOS tick interrupt frequency in Hz (see configTICK_RATE_HZ documentation for more
details).
children.name: FREERTOS_HZ
children.title: configTICK_RATE_HZ

children.help:
Enables port specific task selection method. This option can speed up the search of ready tasks
when scheduling (see configUSE_PORT_OPTIMISED_TASK_SELECTION documentation for more details).
children.name: FREERTOS_OPTIMIZED_SCHEDULER
children.title: configUSE_PORT_OPTIMISED_TASK_SELECTION

children.help: Do not check for stack overflows (configCHECK_FOR_STACK_OVERFLOW = 0)
children.name: FREERTOS_CHECK_STACKOVERFLOW_NONE
children.title: No checking

children.help:
Check for stack overflows on each context switch by checking if the stack pointer is in a valid
range. Quick but does not detect stack overflows that happened between context switches
(configCHECK_FOR_STACK_OVERFLOW = 1)
children.name: FREERTOS_CHECK_STACKOVERFLOW_PTRVAL
children.title: Check by stack pointer value (Method 1)

children.help:
Places some magic bytes at the end of the stack area and on each context switch, check if these
bytes are still intact. More thorough than just checking the pointer, but also slightly slower.
(configCHECK_FOR_STACK_OVERFLOW = 2)
children.name: FREERTOS_CHECK_STACKOVERFLOW_CANARY
children.title: Check using canary bytes (Method 2)

children.help:
Enables FreeRTOS to check for stack overflows (see configCHECK_FOR_STACK_OVERFLOW documentation for
more details).

Note: If users do not provide their own ``vApplicationStackOverflowHook()`` function, a default
function will be provided by ESP-IDF.
children.name: FREERTOS_CHECK_STACKOVERFLOW
children.title: configCHECK_FOR_STACK_OVERFLOW

children.help:
Set the number of thread local storage pointers in each task (see
configNUM_THREAD_LOCAL_STORAGE_POINTERS documentation for more details).

Note: In ESP-IDF, this value must be at least 1. Index 0 is reserved for use by the pthreads API
thread-local-storage. Other indexes can be used for any desired purpose.
children.name: FREERTOS_THREAD_LOCAL_STORAGE_POINTERS
children.title: configNUM_THREAD_LOCAL_STORAGE_POINTERS

children.help:
Sets the idle task stack size in bytes (see configMINIMAL_STACK_SIZE documentation for more details).

Note:

- ESP-IDF specifies stack sizes in bytes instead of words.
- The default size is enough for most use cases.
- The stack size may need to be increased above the default if the app installs idle or thread local
  storage cleanup hooks that use a lot of stack memory.
- Conversely, the stack size can be reduced to the minimum if non of the idle features are used.
children.name: FREERTOS_IDLE_TASK_STACKSIZE
children.title: configMINIMAL_STACK_SIZE (Idle task stack size)

children.help:
Enables the idle task application hook (see configUSE_IDLE_HOOK documentation for more details).

Note:

- The application must provide the hook function ``void vApplicationIdleHook( void );``
- ``vApplicationIdleHook()`` is called from FreeRTOS idle task(s)
- The FreeRTOS idle hook is NOT the same as the ESP-IDF Idle Hook, but both can be enabled
  simultaneously.
children.name: FREERTOS_USE_IDLE_HOOK
children.title: configUSE_IDLE_HOOK

children.help:
Enables the minimal idle task application hook (see configUSE_IDLE_HOOK documentation for more
details).

Note:

- The application must provide the hook function ``void vApplicationPassiveIdleHook( void );``
- ``vApplicationPassiveIdleHook()`` is called from FreeRTOS minimal idle task(s)
children.name: FREERTOS_USE_PASSIVE_IDLE_HOOK
children.title: Use FreeRTOS minimal idle hook

children.help:
Enables the tick hook (see configUSE_TICK_HOOK documentation for more details).

Note:

- The application must provide the hook function ``void vApplicationTickHook( void );``
- ``vApplicationTickHook()`` is called from FreeRTOS's tick handling function ``xTaskIncrementTick()``
- The FreeRTOS tick hook is NOT the same as the ESP-IDF Tick Interrupt Hook, but both can be enabled
  simultaneously.
children.name: FREERTOS_USE_TICK_HOOK
children.title: configUSE_TICK_HOOK

children.help:
Sets the maximum number of characters for task names (see configMAX_TASK_NAME_LEN documentation for
more details).

Note: For most uses, the default of 16 characters is sufficient.
children.name: FREERTOS_MAX_TASK_NAME_LEN
children.title: configMAX_TASK_NAME_LEN

children.help:
Enable backward compatibility with APIs prior to FreeRTOS v8.0.0. (see
configENABLE_BACKWARD_COMPATIBILITY documentation for more details).
children.name: FREERTOS_ENABLE_BACKWARD_COMPATIBILITY
children.title: configENABLE_BACKWARD_COMPATIBILITY

children.help: Sets the timer task's name (see configTIMER_SERVICE_TASK_NAME documentation for more details).
children.name: FREERTOS_TIMER_SERVICE_TASK_NAME
children.title: configTIMER_SERVICE_TASK_NAME

children.help:
Sets the timer task's core affinity
(see configTIMER_SERVICE_TASK_CORE_AFFINITY documentation for more details).
children.name: FREERTOS_TIMER_SERVICE_TASK_CORE_AFFINITY
children.title: configTIMER_SERVICE_TASK_CORE_AFFINITY

children.help: Sets the timer task's priority (see configTIMER_TASK_PRIORITY documentation for more details).
children.name: FREERTOS_TIMER_TASK_PRIORITY
children.title: configTIMER_TASK_PRIORITY

children.help: Set the timer task's stack size (see configTIMER_TASK_STACK_DEPTH documentation for more details).
children.name: FREERTOS_TIMER_TASK_STACK_DEPTH
children.title: configTIMER_TASK_STACK_DEPTH

children.help:
Set the timer task's command queue length (see configTIMER_QUEUE_LENGTH documentation for more
details).
children.name: FREERTOS_TIMER_QUEUE_LENGTH
children.title: configTIMER_QUEUE_LENGTH

children.help:
Enable FreeRTOS Software Timers. Normally the timer task will only get pulled into the build
and created if any software timer related functions are used. This is achieved through IDF
defining a weak empty function for xTimerCreateTimerTask, which should take effect if timers.c
is not pulled into the build.

In certain special cases (if you use configUSE_TRACE_FACILITY=y and event groups) the linker will
still pull in the xTimerCreateTimerTask from timers.c even if the function that utilized it gets
discarded due to not being used.

In these cases you can use this option to force the timer task to be disabled.
children.name: FREERTOS_USE_TIMERS
children.title: configUSE_TIMERS

children.help:
Set the size of the queue registry (see configQUEUE_REGISTRY_SIZE documentation for more details).

Note: A value of 0 will disable queue registry functionality
children.name: FREERTOS_QUEUE_REGISTRY_SIZE
children.title: configQUEUE_REGISTRY_SIZE

children.help:
Set the size of the task notification array of each task. When increasing this value, keep in
mind that this means additional memory for each and every task on the system.
However, task notifications in general are more light weight compared to alternatives
such as semaphores.
children.name: FREERTOS_TASK_NOTIFICATION_ARRAY_ENTRIES
children.title: configTASK_NOTIFICATION_ARRAY_ENTRIES

children.help:
Set configUSE_TRACE_FACILITY and configUSE_STATS_FORMATTING_FUNCTIONS to 1 to include the
``vTaskList()`` and ``vTaskGetRunTimeStats()`` functions in the build (see
configUSE_STATS_FORMATTING_FUNCTIONS documentation for more details).
children.name: FREERTOS_USE_STATS_FORMATTING_FUNCTIONS
children.title: configUSE_STATS_FORMATTING_FUNCTIONS

children.help:
Enables additional structure members and functions to assist with execution visualization and tracing
(see configUSE_TRACE_FACILITY documentation for more details).
children.name: FREERTOS_USE_TRACE_FACILITY
children.title: configUSE_TRACE_FACILITY

children.help:
Enable list integrity checker
(see configUSE_LIST_DATA_INTEGRITY_CHECK_BYTES documentation for more details).
children.name: FREERTOS_USE_LIST_DATA_INTEGRITY_CHECK_BYTES
children.title: configUSE_LIST_DATA_INTEGRITY_CHECK_BYTES

children.help:
If enabled, this will include an extra column when vTaskList is called to display the CoreID the task
is pinned to (0,1) or -1 if not pinned.
children.name: FREERTOS_VTASKLIST_INCLUDE_COREID
children.title: Enable display of xCoreID in vTaskList

children.help: configRUN_TIME_COUNTER_TYPE is set to uint32_t
children.name: FREERTOS_RUN_TIME_COUNTER_TYPE_U32
children.title: uint32_t

children.help: configRUN_TIME_COUNTER_TYPE is set to uint64_t
children.name: FREERTOS_RUN_TIME_COUNTER_TYPE_U64
children.title: uint64_t

children.help:
Sets the data type used for the FreeRTOS run time stats. A larger data type can be used to reduce the
frequency of the counter overflowing.
children.name: FREERTOS_RUN_TIME_COUNTER_TYPE
children.title: configRUN_TIME_COUNTER_TYPE

children.help:
Enables collection of run time statistics for each task (see configGENERATE_RUN_TIME_STATS
documentation for more details).

Note: The clock used for run time statistics can be configured in FREERTOS_RUN_TIME_STATS_CLK.
children.name: FREERTOS_GENERATE_RUN_TIME_STATS
children.title: configGENERATE_RUN_TIME_STATS

children.help:
FreeRTOS will enter light sleep mode if no tasks need to run for this number of ticks.
You can enable PM_PROFILING feature in esp_pm components and dump the sleep status with
esp_pm_dump_locks, if the proportion of rejected sleeps is too high, please increase
this value to improve scheduling efficiency
children.name: FREERTOS_IDLE_TIME_BEFORE_SLEEP
children.title: configEXPECTED_IDLE_TIME_BEFORE_SLEEP

children.help:
If power management support is enabled, FreeRTOS will be able to put the system into light sleep mode
when no tasks need to run for a number of ticks. This number can be set using
FREERTOS_IDLE_TIME_BEFORE_SLEEP option. This feature is also known as "automatic light sleep".

Note that timers created using esp_timer APIs may prevent the system from entering sleep mode, even
when no tasks need to run. To skip unnecessary wake-up initialize a timer with the
"skip_unhandled_events" option as true.

If disabled, automatic light sleep support will be disabled.
children.name: FREERTOS_USE_TICKLESS_IDLE
children.title: configUSE_TICKLESS_IDLE

children.help:
Enables task tagging functionality and its associated API (see configUSE_APPLICATION_TASK_TAG
documentation for more details).
children.name: FREERTOS_USE_APPLICATION_TASK_TAG
children.title: configUSE_APPLICATION_TASK_TAG

children.help:
If enabled, all FreeRTOS task functions will be enclosed in a wrapper function. If a task function
mistakenly returns (i.e. does not delete), the call flow will return to the wrapper function. The
wrapper function will then log an error and abort the application. This option is also required for GDB
backtraces and C++ exceptions to work correctly inside top-level task functions.
children.name: FREERTOS_TASK_FUNCTION_WRAPPER
children.title: Wrap task functions

children.help:
FreeRTOS can check if a stack has overflown its bounds by checking either the value of the stack
pointer or by checking the integrity of canary bytes. (See FREERTOS_CHECK_STACKOVERFLOW for more
information.) These checks only happen on a context switch, and the situation that caused the stack
overflow may already be long gone by then. This option will use the last debug memory watchpoint to
allow breaking into the debugger (or panic'ing) as soon as any of the last 32 bytes on the stack of a
task are overwritten. The side effect is that using gdb, you effectively have one hardware watchpoint
less because the last one is overwritten as soon as a task switch happens.

Another consequence is that due to alignment requirements of the watchpoint, the usable stack size
decreases by up to 60 bytes. This is because the watchpoint region has to be aligned to its size and
the size for the stack watchpoint in IDF is 32 bytes.

This check only triggers if the stack overflow writes within 32 bytes near the end of the stack, rather
than overshooting further, so it is worth combining this approach with one of the other stack overflow
check methods.

When this watchpoint is hit, gdb will stop with a SIGTRAP message. When no JTAG OCD is attached,
esp-idf will panic on an unhandled debug exception.
children.name: FREERTOS_WATCHPOINT_END_OF_STACK
children.title: Enable stack overflow debug watchpoint

children.help:
ESP-IDF provides users with the ability to free TLSP memory by registering TLSP deletion callbacks.
These callbacks are automatically called by FreeRTOS when a task is deleted. When this option is turned
on, the memory reserved for TLSPs in the TCB is doubled to make space for storing the deletion
callbacks. If the user does not wish to use TLSP deletion callbacks then this option could be turned
off to save space in the TCB memory.
children.name: FREERTOS_TLSP_DELETION_CALLBACKS
children.title: Enable thread local storage pointers deletion callbacks

children.help:
Enable this option to make FreeRTOS call a user provided hook function right before it deletes a task
(i.e., frees/releases a dynamically/statically allocated task's memory). This is useful if users want
to know when a task is actually deleted (in case the task's deletion is delegated to the IDLE task).

If this config option is enabled, users must define a ``void vTaskPreDeletionHook( void * pxTCB )``
hook function in their application.
children.name: FREERTOS_TASK_PRE_DELETION_HOOK
children.title: Enable task pre-deletion hook

children.help:
THIS OPTION IS DEPRECATED. Use FREERTOS_TASK_PRE_DELETION_HOOK instead.

Enable this option to make FreeRTOS call the static task clean up hook when a task is deleted.

Note: Users will need to provide a ``void vPortCleanUpTCB ( void *pxTCB )`` callback
children.name: FREERTOS_ENABLE_STATIC_TASK_CLEAN_UP
children.title: Enable static task clean up hook (DEPRECATED)

children.help:
If enabled, assert that when a mutex semaphore is given, the task giving the semaphore is the task
which is currently holding the mutex.
children.name: FREERTOS_CHECK_MUTEX_GIVEN_BY_OWNER
children.title: Check that mutex semaphore is given by owner task

children.help:
The interrupt handlers have their own stack. The size of the stack can be defined here. Each processor
has its own stack, so the total size occupied will be twice this.
children.name: FREERTOS_ISR_STACKSIZE
children.title: ISR stack size

children.help:
If this option is enabled, interrupt stack frame will be modified to point to the code of the
interrupted task as its return address. This helps the debugger (or the panic handler) show a backtrace
from the interrupt to the task which was interrupted. This also works for nested interrupts: higher
level interrupt stack can be traced back to the lower level interrupt. This option adds 4 instructions
to the interrupt dispatching code.
children.name: FREERTOS_INTERRUPT_BACKTRACE
children.title: Enable backtrace from interrupt to task context

children.help:
When enabled, the usage of float type is allowed inside Level 1 ISRs. Note that usage of float types in
higher level interrupts is still not permitted.
children.name: FREERTOS_FPU_IN_ISR
children.title: Use float in Level 1 ISR

children.help: Select this to use timer 0
children.name: FREERTOS_CORETIMER_0
children.title: Timer 0 (int 6, level 1)

children.help: Select this to use timer 1
children.name: FREERTOS_CORETIMER_1
children.title: Timer 1 (int 15, level 3)

children.help: Select this to use systimer with the 1 interrupt priority.
children.name: FREERTOS_CORETIMER_SYSTIMER_LVL1
children.title: SYSTIMER 0 (level 1)

children.help: Select this to use systimer with the 3 interrupt priority.
children.name: FREERTOS_CORETIMER_SYSTIMER_LVL3
children.title: SYSTIMER 0 (level 3)

children.help:
FreeRTOS needs a timer with an associated interrupt to use as the main tick source to increase
counters, run timers and do pre-emptive multitasking with. There are multiple timers available to do
this, with different interrupt priorities.
children.name: FREERTOS_CORETIMER
children.title: Tick timer source (Xtensa Only)

children.help:
ESP Timer will be used as the clock source for FreeRTOS run time stats. The ESP Timer runs at a
frequency of 1MHz regardless of Dynamic Frequency Scaling. Therefore the ESP Timer will overflow in
approximately 4290 seconds.
children.name: FREERTOS_RUN_TIME_STATS_USING_ESP_TIMER
children.title: Use ESP TIMER for run time stats

children.help:
CPU Clock will be used as the clock source for the generation of run time stats. The CPU Clock has
a frequency dependent on ESP_DEFAULT_CPU_FREQ_MHZ and Dynamic Frequency Scaling (DFS). Therefore
the CPU Clock frequency can fluctuate between 80 to 240MHz. Run time stats generated using the CPU
Clock represents the number of CPU cycles each task is allocated and DOES NOT reflect the amount of
time each task runs for (as CPU clock frequency can change). If the CPU clock consistently runs at
the maximum frequency of 240MHz, it will overflow in approximately 17 seconds.
children.name: FREERTOS_RUN_TIME_STATS_USING_CPU_CLK
children.title: Use CPU Clock for run time stats

children.help:
Choose the clock source for FreeRTOS run time stats. Options are CPU0's CPU Clock or the ESP Timer.
Both clock sources are 32 bits. The CPU Clock can run at a higher frequency hence provide a finer
resolution but will overflow much quicker. Note that run time stats are only valid until the clock
source overflows.
children.name: FREERTOS_RUN_TIME_STATS_CLK
children.title: Choose the clock source for run time stats

children.help:
When enabled the selected Non-ISR FreeRTOS functions will be placed into Flash memory instead of IRAM.
This saves up to 8KB of IRAM depending on which functions are used.
children.name: FREERTOS_PLACE_FUNCTIONS_INTO_FLASH
children.title: Place FreeRTOS functions into Flash

children.help:
If enabled, context of port*_CRITICAL calls (ISR or Non-ISR) would be checked to be in compliance with
Vanilla FreeRTOS. e.g Calling port*_CRITICAL from ISR context would cause assert failure
children.name: FREERTOS_CHECK_PORT_CRITICAL_COMPLIANCE
children.title: Tests compliance with Vanilla FreeRTOS port*_CRITICAL calls

children.help:
Accessing memory in PSRAM has certain restrictions, so task stacks allocated by xTaskCreate
are by default allocated from internal RAM.

This option allows for passing memory allocated from SPIRAM to be passed to xTaskCreateStatic.
This should only be used for tasks where the stack is never accessed while the cache is disabled.

Extra notes for ESP32:

Because some bits of the ESP32 code environment cannot be recompiled with the cache workaround,
normally tasks cannot be safely run with their stack residing in external memory; for this reason
xTaskCreate (and related task creation functions) always allocate stack in internal memory and
xTaskCreateStatic will check if the memory passed to it is in internal memory.
If you have a task that needs a large amount of stack and does not call on ROM code in any way
(no direct calls, but also no Bluetooth/WiFi), you can try enable this to
cause xTaskCreateStatic to allow tasks stack in external memory.
children.name: FREERTOS_TASK_CREATE_ALLOW_EXT_MEM
children.title: Allow external memory as an argument to xTaskCreateStatic (READ HELP)

children.help: Hidden option, gets selected by CONFIG_ESP_DEBUG_OCDAWARE
children.name: FREERTOS_DEBUG_OCDAWARE

children.help:
Set the assert behavior / level for HAL component.
HAL component assert level can be set separately,
but the level can't exceed the system assertion level.
e.g. If the system assertion is disabled, then the HAL
assertion can't be enabled either. If the system assertion
is enable, then the HAL assertion can still be disabled
by this Kconfig option.
children.name: HAL_DEFAULT_ASSERTION_LEVEL
children.title: Default HAL assertion level

children.help: Specify how much output to see in HAL logs.
children.name: HAL_LOG_LEVEL
children.title: HAL layer log verbosity

children.help:
Enable this flag to use HAL functions from ROM instead of ESP-IDF.

If keeping this as "n" in your project, you will have less free IRAM.
If making this as "y" in your project, you will increase free IRAM,
but you will lose the possibility to debug this module, and some new
features will be added and bugs will be fixed in the IDF source
but cannot be synced to ROM.
children.name: HAL_SYSTIMER_USE_ROM_IMPL
children.title: Use ROM implementation of SysTimer HAL driver

children.help:
Enable this flag to use HAL functions from ROM instead of ESP-IDF.

If keeping this as "n" in your project, you will have less free IRAM.
If making this as "y" in your project, you will increase free IRAM,
but you will lose the possibility to debug this module, and some new
features will be added and bugs will be fixed in the IDF source
but cannot be synced to ROM.
children.name: HAL_WDT_USE_ROM_IMPL
children.title: Use ROM implementation of WDT HAL driver

children.help: Enable this option to place SPI master hal layer functions into IRAM.
children.name: HAL_SPI_MASTER_FUNC_IN_IRAM

children.help: Enable this option to place SPI slave hal layer functions into IRAM.
children.name: HAL_SPI_SLAVE_FUNC_IN_IRAM

children.help:
Enable this option to apply the countermeasure for ECDSA signature operation
This countermeasure masks the real ECDSA sign operation
under dummy sign operations to add randomness in the generated power signature.
children.name: HAL_ECDSA_GEN_SIG_CM
children.title: Enable countermeasure for ECDSA signature generation
Hardware Abstraction Layer (HAL) and Low Level (LL)

children.help:
Enable heap poisoning features to detect heap corruption caused by out-of-bounds access to heap memory.

See the "Heap Memory Debugging" page of the IDF documentation
for a description of each level of heap corruption detection.
children.name: HEAP_CORRUPTION_DETECTION
children.title: Heap corruption detection

children.help:
Enables the heap tracing API defined in esp_heap_trace.h.

This function causes a moderate increase in IRAM code side and a minor increase in heap function
(malloc/free/realloc) CPU overhead, even when the tracing feature is not used.
So it's best to keep it disabled unless tracing is being used.
children.name: HEAP_TRACING_DEST
children.title: Heap tracing

children.help: Enables/disables heap tracing API.
children.name: HEAP_TRACING

children.help:
Number of stack frames to save when tracing heap operation callers.

More stack frames uses more memory in the heap trace buffer (and slows down allocation), but
can provide useful information.
children.name: HEAP_TRACING_STACK_DEPTH
children.title: Heap tracing stack depth

children.help: Enable the user to implement function hooks triggered for each successful allocation and free.
children.name: HEAP_USE_HOOKS
children.title: Use allocation and free hooks

children.help:
Enables tracking the task responsible for each heap allocation.

This function depends on heap poisoning being enabled and adds four more bytes of overhead for each block
allocated.
children.name: HEAP_TASK_TRACKING
children.title: Enable heap task tracking

children.help: When enabled this configuration forces the hash map to be placed in external RAM.
children.name: HEAP_TRACE_HASH_MAP_IN_EXT_RAM
children.title: Place hash map in external RAM

children.help:
Defines the number of entries in the heap trace hashmap. Each entry takes 8 bytes.
The bigger this number is, the better the performance. Recommended range: 200 - 2000.
children.name: HEAP_TRACE_HASH_MAP_SIZE
children.title: The number of entries in the hash map

children.help:
Enable this flag to use a hash map to increase performance in handling
heap trace records.

Heap trace standalone supports storing records as a list, or a list + hash map.

Using only a list takes less memory, but calls to 'free' will get slower as the
list grows. This is particularly affected when using HEAP_TRACE_ALL mode.

By using a list + hash map, calls to 'free' remain fast, at the cost of
additional memory to store the hash map.
children.name: HEAP_TRACE_HASH_MAP
children.title: Use hash map mechanism to access heap trace records

children.help: When enabled, if a memory allocation operation fails it will cause a system abort.
children.name: HEAP_ABORT_WHEN_ALLOCATION_FAILS
children.title: Abort if memory allocation fails

children.help:
Enable this flag to use heap functions from ROM instead of ESP-IDF.

If keeping this as "n" in your project, you will have less free IRAM.
If making this as "y" in your project, you will increase free IRAM,
but you will lose the possibility to debug this module, and some new
features will be added and bugs will be fixed in the IDF source
but cannot be synced to ROM.
children.name: HEAP_TLSF_USE_ROM_IMPL
children.title: Use ROM implementation of heap tlsf library

children.help:
Enable this flag to save up RAM space by placing the heap component in the flash memory

Note that it is only safe to enable this configuration if no functions from esp_heap_caps.h
or esp_heap_trace.h are called from ISR.
children.name: HEAP_PLACE_FUNCTION_INTO_FLASH
children.title: Force the entire heap component to be placed in flash memory

children.help:
Specify how much output to see in logs by default.
You can set lower verbosity level at runtime using
esp_log_level_set() function if LOG_DYNAMIC_LEVEL_CONTROL
is enabled.

By default, this setting limits which log statements
are compiled into the program. For example, selecting
"Warning" would mean that changing log level to "Debug"
at runtime will not be possible. To allow increasing log
level above the default at runtime, see the next option.
children.name: LOG_DEFAULT_LEVEL
children.title: Default log verbosity

children.help:
This config option sets the highest log verbosity that it's possible to select
at runtime by calling esp_log_level_set(). This level may be higher than
the default verbosity level which is set when the app starts up.

This can be used enable debugging output only at a critical point, for a particular
tag, or to minimize startup time but then enable more logs once the firmware has
loaded.

Note that increasing the maximum available log level will increase the firmware
binary size.

This option only applies to logging from the app, the bootloader log level is
fixed at compile time to the separate "Bootloader log verbosity" setting.
children.name: LOG_MAXIMUM_LEVEL
children.title: Maximum log verbosity

children.help:
Enables an additional global "master" log level check that occurs before a log tag cache
lookup. This is useful if you want to compile in a lot of logs that are selectable at
runtime, but avoid the performance hit during periods where you don't want log output.

Examples include remote log forwarding, or disabling logs during a time-critical or
CPU-intensive section and re-enabling them later. Results in larger program size
depending on number of logs compiled in.

If enabled, defaults to LOG_DEFAULT_LEVEL and can be set using
esp_log_set_level_master(). This check takes precedence over ESP_LOG_LEVEL_LOCAL.
children.name: LOG_MASTER_LEVEL
children.title: Enable global master log level

children.help:
Enabling this option allows dynamic changes to the log level at runtime
(using esp_log_level_set()), providing the ability to increase or decrease
the log level during program execution.
If disabled, the log level remains static once set at compile-time and calling
esp_log_level_set() will have no effect.
If binary size is a critical consideration and dynamic log level changes are not needed,
consider disabling this option when LOG_TAG_LEVEL_IMPL_NONE=y to minimize program size.
children.name: LOG_DYNAMIC_LEVEL_CONTROL
children.title: Enable dynamic log level changes at runtime

children.help:
This option disables the ability to set the log level per tag.
The ability to change the log level at runtime depends on LOG_DYNAMIC_LEVEL_CONTROL.
If LOG_DYNAMIC_LEVEL_CONTROL is disabled, then changing the log level at runtime
using `esp_log_level_set()` is not possible.
This implementation is suitable for highly constrained environments.
children.name: LOG_TAG_LEVEL_IMPL_NONE
children.title: None

children.help:
Select this option to use the linked list-only implementation (no cache) for log level retrieval.
This approach searches the linked list of all tags for the log level, which may be slower
for a large number of tags but may have lower memory requirements than the CACHE approach.
The linked list approach compares the whole strings of log tags for finding the log level.
children.name: LOG_TAG_LEVEL_IMPL_LINKED_LIST
children.title: Linked List

children.help:
Select this option to use a hybrid mode: cache in combination with the linked list
for log tag level checks. This hybrid approach offers a balance between speed and memory usage.

The cache stores recently accessed log tags and their corresponding log levels, providing
faster lookups for frequently used tags. The cache approach compares the tag pointers, which is
faster than comparing the whole strings.

For less frequently used tags, the linked list is used to search for the log level, which may be
slower for a large number of tags but has lower memory requirements compared to a full cache.

This hybrid approach aims to improve the efficiency of log level retrieval by combining the benefits
of both cache and linked list implementations.
children.name: LOG_TAG_LEVEL_IMPL_CACHE_AND_LINKED_LIST
children.title: Cache + Linked List

children.help:
Choose the per-tag log level implementation for the log library. This functionality is used
to enable/disable logs for a particular tag at run time. Applicable only for
application logs (i.e., not bootloader logs).
children.name: LOG_TAG_LEVEL_IMPL
children.title: Method of tag level checks

children.help:
This option enables the use of a simple array-based cache implementation for storing and
retrieving log tag levels. There is no additional code that reorders the cache for fast lookups.
Suitable for projects where memory usage optimization is crucial and the simplicity of implementation
is preferred.
children.name: LOG_TAG_LEVEL_CACHE_ARRAY
children.title: Array

children.help:
This option enables the use of a binary min-heap-based cache implementation for efficient
storage and retrieval of log tag levels. It does automatically optimizing cache for fast lookups.
Suitable for projects where speed of lookup is critical and memory usage can accommodate
the overhead of maintaining a binary min-heap structure.
children.name: LOG_TAG_LEVEL_CACHE_BINARY_MIN_HEAP
children.title: Binary Min-Heap

children.help:
The cache stores recently accessed log tags (address of tag) and their corresponding log levels,
providing faster lookups for frequently used tags. Cache size can be configured using the
LOG_TAG_LEVEL_IMPL_CACHE_SIZE option. The cache approach compares the tag pointers, which is
faster than comparing the whole strings.
children.name: LOG_TAG_LEVEL_CACHE_IMPL
children.title: Cache implementation

children.help:
This option sets the size of the cache used for log tag entries. The cache stores recently accessed
log tags and their corresponding log levels, which helps improve the efficiency of log level retrieval.
The value must be a power of 2 minus 1 (e.g., 1, 3, 7, 15, 31, 63, 127, 255, ...)
to ensure proper cache behavior. For LOG_TAG_LEVEL_CACHE_ARRAY option the value can be any,
without restrictions.

Note: A larger cache size can improve lookup performance for frequently used log tags but may consume
more memory. Conversely, a smaller cache size reduces memory usage but may lead to more frequent cache
evictions for less frequently used log tags.
children.name: LOG_TAG_LEVEL_IMPL_CACHE_SIZE
children.title: Log Tag Cache Size

children.help:
Enable ANSI terminal color codes.
In order to view these, your terminal program must support ANSI color codes.
children.name: LOG_COLORS
children.title: Color

children.help:
Choose what sort of timestamp is displayed in the log output:

- "None" - The log will only contain the actual log messages themselves
  without any time-related information. Avoiding timestamps can help conserve
  processing power and memory. It might useful when you
  perform log analysis or debugging, sometimes it's more straightforward
  to work with logs that lack timestamps, especially if the time of occurrence
  is not critical for understanding the issues.

- "Milliseconds since boot" is calculated from the RTOS tick count multiplied
  by the tick period. This time will reset after a software reboot.
  e.g. (90000)

- "System time (HH:MM:SS.sss)" is taken from POSIX time functions which use the chip's
  RTC and high resolution timers to maintain an accurate time. The system time is
  initialized to 0 on startup, it can be set with an SNTP sync, or with
  POSIX time functions. This time will not reset after a software reboot.
  e.g. (00:01:30.000)

- "System time (YY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS.sss)" it is the same as the above,
  but also prints the date as well.

- NOTE: Currently this will not get used in logging from binary blobs
  (i.e WiFi & Bluetooth libraries), these will always print
  milliseconds since boot.
children.name: LOG_TIMESTAMP_SOURCE
children.title: Timestamp

children.help:
Builds normally if selected. Excludes LwIP from build if unselected, even if it is a
dependency of a component or application.
Some applications can switch their IP stacks, e.g., when switching between chip
and Linux targets (LwIP stack vs. Linux IP stack). Since the LwIP dependency cannot
easily be excluded based on a Kconfig option, it has to be a dependency in all cases.
This switch allows the LwIP stack to be built selectively, even if it is a dependency.
children.name: LWIP_ENABLE
children.title: Enable LwIP stack

children.help:
The default name this device will report to other devices on the network.
Could be updated at runtime with esp_netif_set_hostname()
children.name: LWIP_LOCAL_HOSTNAME
children.title: Local netif hostname

children.help:
If this feature is enabled, standard POSIX APIs: if_indextoname(), if_nametoindex()
could be used to convert network interface index to name
instead of IDF specific esp-netif APIs (such as esp_netif_get_netif_impl_name())
children.name: LWIP_NETIF_API
children.title: Enable usage of standard POSIX APIs in LWIP

children.help:
LWIP tcpip task priority. In case of high throughput, this parameter
could be changed up to (configMAX_PRIORITIES-1).
children.name: LWIP_TCPIP_TASK_PRIO
children.title: LWIP TCP/IP Task Priority

children.help:
when LWIP_TCPIP_CORE_LOCKING is enabled, this lets tcpip_input() grab the
mutex for input packets as well, instead of allocating a message and passing
it to tcpip_thread.
children.name: LWIP_TCPIP_CORE_LOCKING_INPUT
children.title: Enable tcpip core locking input

children.help:
If Enable tcpip core locking,Creates a global mutex that is held
during TCPIP thread operations.Can be locked by client code to perform
lwIP operations without changing into TCPIP thread using callbacks.
See LOCK_TCPIP_CORE() and UNLOCK_TCPIP_CORE().

If disable tcpip core locking,TCP IP will perform tasks through context switching
children.name: LWIP_TCPIP_CORE_LOCKING
children.title: Enable tcpip core locking

children.help:
Enable to check that the project does not violate lwip thread safety.
If enabled, all lwip functions that require thread awareness run an assertion
to verify that the TCP/IP core functionality is either locked or accessed
from the correct thread.
children.name: LWIP_CHECK_THREAD_SAFETY
children.title: Checks that lwip API runs in expected context

children.help:
If this feature is enabled, standard API such as gethostbyname
support .local addresses by sending one shot multicast mDNS
query
children.name: LWIP_DNS_SUPPORT_MDNS_QUERIES
children.title: Enable mDNS queries in resolving host name

children.help:
If this feature is enabled, all traffic from layer2(WIFI Driver) will be
copied to a new buffer before sending it to layer3(LWIP stack), freeing
the layer2 buffer.
Please be notified that the total layer2 receiving buffer is fixed and
ESP32 currently supports 25 layer2 receiving buffer, when layer2 buffer
runs out of memory, then the incoming packets will be dropped in hardware.
The layer3 buffer is allocated from the heap, so the total layer3 receiving
buffer depends on the available heap size, when heap runs out of memory,
no copy will be sent to layer3 and packet will be dropped in layer2.
Please make sure you fully understand the impact of this feature before
enabling it.
children.name: LWIP_L2_TO_L3_COPY
children.title: Enable copy between Layer2 and Layer3 packets

children.help:
If this feature is enabled, some functions relating to RX/TX in LWIP will be
put into IRAM, it can improve UDP/TCP throughput by >10% for single core mode,
it doesn't help too much for dual core mode. On the other hand, it needs about
10KB IRAM for these optimizations.

If this feature is disabled, all lwip functions will be put into FLASH.
children.name: LWIP_IRAM_OPTIMIZATION
children.title: Enable LWIP IRAM optimization

children.help:
If this feature is enabled, some tcp part functions relating to RX/TX in LWIP will be
put into IRAM, it can improve TCP throughput. On the other hand, it needs about 17KB
IRAM for these optimizations.
children.name: LWIP_EXTRA_IRAM_OPTIMIZATION
children.title: Enable LWIP IRAM optimization for TCP part

children.help:
If this feature is enabled, IGMP and MLD6 timers will be activated only
when joining groups or receiving QUERY packets.

This feature will reduce the power consumption for applications which do not
use IGMP and MLD6.
children.name: LWIP_TIMERS_ONDEMAND
children.title: Enable LWIP Timers on demand

children.help:
This option is used to set the the router flag for the NA packets.
When enabled, the router flag in NA packet will always set to 1,
otherwise, never set router flag for NA packets.
children.name: LWIP_FORCE_ROUTER_FORWARDING
children.title: LWIP Force Router Forwarding Enable/Disable

children.help:
This option is used to disable the Network Discovery Protocol (NDP) if it is not required.
Please use this option with caution, as the NDP is essential for IPv6 functionality within a local network.
children.name: LWIP_ND6
children.title: LWIP NDP6 Enable/Disable

children.help:
The practical maximum limit is
determined by available heap memory at runtime.

Sockets take up a certain amount of memory, and allowing fewer
sockets to be open at the same time conserves memory. Specify
the maximum amount of sockets here. The valid value is from 1
to 253. If using value above 61, update CMakeLists defining
FD_SETSIZE to the number of sockets used plus the
expected open files (minimum of +3 for stdout, stderr and stdin).
children.name: LWIP_MAX_SOCKETS
children.title: Max number of open sockets

children.help: This option is deprecated. Do not use this option, use VFS_SUPPORT_SELECT instead.
children.name: LWIP_USE_ONLY_LWIP_SELECT
children.title: Support LWIP socket select() only (DEPRECATED)

children.help:
Enabling this option allows SO_LINGER processing.
l_onoff = 1,l_linger can set the timeout.

If l_linger=0, When a connection is closed, TCP will terminate the connection.
This means that TCP will discard any data packets stored in the socket send buffer
and send an RST to the peer.

If l_linger!=0,Then closesocket() calls to block the process until
the remaining data packets has been sent or timed out.
children.name: LWIP_SO_LINGER
children.title: Enable SO_LINGER processing

children.help:
Enabling this option means that any incoming broadcast or multicast
packet will be copied to all of the local sockets that it matches
(may be more than one if SO_REUSEADDR is set on the socket.)

This increases memory overhead as the packets need to be copied,
however they are only copied per matching socket. You can safely
disable it if you don't plan to receive broadcast or multicast
traffic on more than one socket at a time.
children.name: LWIP_SO_REUSE_RXTOALL
children.title: SO_REUSEADDR copies broadcast/multicast to all matches

children.help:
Enabling this option allows binding to a port which remains in
TIME_WAIT.
children.name: LWIP_SO_REUSE
children.title: Enable SO_REUSEADDR option

children.help: Enabling this option allows checking for available data on a netconn.
children.name: LWIP_SO_RCVBUF
children.title: Enable SO_RCVBUF option

children.help:
Enabling this option allows checking for the destination address
of a received IPv4 Packet.
children.name: LWIP_NETBUF_RECVINFO
children.title: Enable IP_PKTINFO option

children.help: Set value for Time-To-Live used by transport layers.
children.name: LWIP_IP_DEFAULT_TTL
children.title: The value for Time-To-Live used by transport layers

children.help:
Enabling this option allows fragmenting outgoing IP4 packets if their size
exceeds MTU.
children.name: LWIP_IP4_FRAG
children.title: Enable fragment outgoing IP4 packets

children.help:
Enabling this option allows fragmenting outgoing IP6 packets if their size
exceeds MTU.
children.name: LWIP_IP6_FRAG
children.title: Enable fragment outgoing IP6 packets

children.help: Enabling this option allows reassemblying incoming fragmented IP4 packets.
children.name: LWIP_IP4_REASSEMBLY
children.title: Enable reassembly incoming fragmented IP4 packets

children.help: Enabling this option allows reassemblying incoming fragmented IP6 packets.
children.name: LWIP_IP6_REASSEMBLY
children.title: Enable reassembly incoming fragmented IP6 packets

children.help: Set the maximum amount of pbufs waiting to be reassembled.
children.name: LWIP_IP_REASS_MAX_PBUFS
children.title: The maximum amount of pbufs waiting to be reassembled

children.help: Enabling this option allows Port Forwarding or Port mapping.
children.name: LWIP_IPV4_NAPT_PORTMAP
children.title: Enable NAT Port Mapping

children.help: Enabling this option allows Network Address and Port Translation.
children.name: LWIP_IPV4_NAPT
children.title: Enable NAT

children.help: Enabling this option allows packets forwarding across multiple interfaces.
children.name: LWIP_IP_FORWARD
children.title: Enable IP forwarding

children.help: Enabling this option allows LWIP statistics
children.name: LWIP_STATS
children.title: Enable LWIP statistics

children.help: Set the timer interval for gratuitous ARP. The default value is 60s
children.name: LWIP_GARP_TMR_INTERVAL
children.title: GARP timer interval(seconds)

children.help:
Enable this option allows to send gratuitous ARP periodically.

This option solve the compatibility issues.If the ARP table of the AP is old, and the AP
doesn't send ARP request to update it's ARP table, this will lead to the STA sending IP packet fail.
Thus we send gratuitous ARP periodically to let AP update it's ARP table.
children.name: LWIP_ESP_GRATUITOUS_ARP
children.title: Send gratuitous ARP periodically

children.help: Set the timer interval for mldv6 report. The default value is 30s
children.name: LWIP_MLDV6_TMR_INTERVAL
children.title: mldv6 report timer interval(seconds)

children.help:
Enable this option allows to send mldv6 report periodically.

This option solve the issue that failed to receive multicast data.
Some routers fail to forward multicast packets.
To solve this problem, send multicast mdlv6 report to routers regularly.
children.name: LWIP_ESP_MLDV6_REPORT
children.title: Send mldv6 report periodically

children.help:
Set TCPIP task receive mail box size. Generally bigger value means higher throughput
but more memory. The value should be bigger than UDP/TCP mail box size.
children.name: LWIP_TCPIP_RECVMBOX_SIZE
children.title: TCPIP task receive mail box size

children.name: LWIP_DHCP_DOES_NOT_CHECK_OFFERED_IP
children.title: DHCP does not detect conflict on the offered IP

children.help:
Choose the preferred way of DHCP client to check if the offered address
is available:
* Using Address Conflict Detection (ACD) module assures that the offered IP address
is properly probed and announced before binding in DHCP. This conforms to RFC5227,
but takes several seconds.
* Using ARP check, we only send two ARP requests to check for replies. This process
lasts 1 - 2 seconds.
* No conflict detection: We directly bind the offered address.
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_CHECKS_OFFERED_ADDRESS
children.title: Choose how DHCP validates offered IP

children.help:
This option could be used to disable DHCP client identification with its MAC address.
(Client id is used by DHCP servers to uniquely identify clients and are included
in the DHCP packets as an option 61)
Set this option to "y" in order to exclude option 61 from DHCP packets.
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_DISABLE_CLIENT_ID
children.title: DHCP: Disable Use of HW address as client identification

children.help:
This option could be used to disable DHCP client vendor class identification.
Set this option to "y" in order to exclude option 60 from DHCP packets.
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_DISABLE_VENDOR_CLASS_ID
children.title: DHCP: Disable Use of vendor class identification

children.help:
When this option is enabled, DHCP client tries to re-obtain last valid IP address obtained from DHCP
server. Last valid DHCP configuration is stored in nvs and restored after reset/power-up. If IP is still
available, there is no need for sending discovery message to DHCP server and save some time.
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_RESTORE_LAST_IP
children.title: DHCP: Restore last IP obtained from DHCP server

children.help:
Set total length of outgoing DHCP option msg. Generally bigger value means it can carry more
options and values. If your code meets LWIP_ASSERT due to option value is too long.
Please increase the LWIP_DHCP_OPTIONS_LEN value.
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_OPTIONS_LEN
children.title: DHCP total option length

children.help: Number of clients that may store data in client_data member array of struct netif.
children.name: LWIP_NUM_NETIF_CLIENT_DATA
children.title: Number of clients store data in netif

children.help:
Set DHCP coarse interval in seconds.
A higher value will be less precise but cost less power consumption.
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_COARSE_TIMER_SECS
children.title: DHCP coarse timer interval(s)

children.help:
The DHCP server is calculating lease time multiplying the sent
and received times by this number of seconds per unit.
The default is 60, that equals one minute.
children.name: LWIP_DHCPS_LEASE_UNIT
children.title: Multiplier for lease time, in seconds

children.help:
The maximum number of DHCP clients that are connected to the server.
After this number is exceeded, DHCP server removes of the oldest device
from it's address pool, without notification.
children.name: LWIP_DHCPS_MAX_STATION_NUM
children.title: Maximum number of stations

children.help:
Enabling this option allows DHCP server to support temporary static ARP entries
for DHCP Client. This will help the DHCP server to send the DHCP OFFER and DHCP ACK using IP unicast.
children.name: LWIP_DHCPS_STATIC_ENTRIES
children.title: Enable ARP static entries

children.help:
Enabling this option allows the device to run the DHCP server
(to dynamically assign IPv4 addresses to clients).
children.name: LWIP_DHCPS
children.title: DHCPS: Enable IPv4 Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol Server (DHCPS)

children.help:
DHCP client will send this many probes before self-assigning a
link local address.

From LWIP help: "This can be set as low as 1 to get an AutoIP
address very quickly, but you should be prepared to handle a
changing IP address when DHCP overrides AutoIP." (In the case of
ESP-IDF, this means multiple SYSTEM_EVENT_STA_GOT_IP events.)
children.name: LWIP_AUTOIP_TRIES
children.title: DHCP Probes before self-assigning IPv4 LL address

children.help:
If the AUTOIP functionality detects this many IP conflicts while
self-assigning an address, it will go into a rate limited mode.
children.name: LWIP_AUTOIP_MAX_CONFLICTS
children.title: Max IP conflicts before rate limiting

children.help:
If rate limiting self-assignment requests, wait this long between
each request.
children.name: LWIP_AUTOIP_RATE_LIMIT_INTERVAL
children.title: Rate limited interval (seconds)

children.help:
Enabling this option allows the device to self-assign an address
in the 169.256/16 range if none is assigned statically or via DHCP.

See RFC 3927.
children.name: LWIP_AUTOIP
children.title: Enable IPV4 Link-Local Addressing (AUTOIP)

children.help: Enable IPv4 stack. If you want to use IPv6 only TCP/IP stack, disable this.
children.name: LWIP_IPV4
children.title: Enable IPv4

children.help:
Enabling this option allows the devices to IPV6 stateless address autoconfiguration (SLAAC).

See RFC 4862.
children.name: LWIP_IPV6_AUTOCONFIG
children.title: Enable IPV6 stateless address autoconfiguration (SLAAC)

children.help:
The maximum number of IPv6 addresses on each interface. Any additional
addresses will be discarded.
children.name: LWIP_IPV6_NUM_ADDRESSES
children.title: Number of IPv6 addresses on each network interface

children.help:
Forwarding IPv6 packets between interfaces is only required when acting as
a router.
children.name: LWIP_IPV6_FORWARD
children.title: Enable IPv6 forwarding between interfaces

children.help:
Enable IPv6 function. If not use IPv6 function, set this option to n.
If disabling LWIP_IPV6 then some other components (asio) will
no longer be available.
children.name: LWIP_IPV6
children.title: Enable IPv6

children.help:
Use IPv6 Router Advertisement Recursive DNS Server Option (as per RFC 6106) to
copy a defined maximum number of DNS servers to the DNS module.
Set this option to a number of desired DNS servers advertised in the RA protocol.
This feature is disabled when set to 0.
children.name: LWIP_IPV6_RDNSS_MAX_DNS_SERVERS
children.title: Use IPv6 Router Advertisement Recursive DNS Server Option

children.name: LWIP_IPV6_DHCP6
children.title: Enable DHCPv6 stateless address autoconfiguration

children.help: Enable callbacks when the network interface is up/down and addresses are changed.
children.name: LWIP_NETIF_STATUS_CALLBACK
children.title: Enable status callback for network interfaces

children.help:
Configure the maximum number of packets which can be queued for
loopback on a given interface. Reducing this number may cause packets
to be dropped, but will avoid filling memory with queued packet data.
children.name: LWIP_LOOPBACK_MAX_PBUFS
children.title: Max queued loopback packets per interface

children.help:
Enabling this option means that if a packet is sent with a destination
address equal to the interface's own IP address, it will "loop back" and
be received by this interface.
Disabling this option disables support of loopback interface in lwIP
children.name: LWIP_NETIF_LOOPBACK
children.title: Support per-interface loopback

children.help:
The maximum number of simultaneously active TCP
connections. The practical maximum limit is
determined by available heap memory at runtime.

Changing this value by itself does not substantially
change the memory usage of LWIP, except for preventing
new TCP connections after the limit is reached.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_ACTIVE_TCP
children.title: Maximum active TCP Connections

children.help:
The maximum number of simultaneously listening TCP
connections. The practical maximum limit is
determined by available heap memory at runtime.

Changing this value by itself does not substantially
change the memory usage of LWIP, except for preventing
new listening TCP connections after the limit is reached.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_LISTENING_TCP
children.title: Maximum listening TCP Connections

children.help:
Speed up the TCP retransmission interval. If disabled,
it is recommended to change the number of SYN retransmissions to 6,
and TCP initial rto time to 3000.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_HIGH_SPEED_RETRANSMISSION
children.title: TCP high speed retransmissions

children.help: Set maximum number of retransmissions of data segments.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_MAXRTX
children.title: Maximum number of retransmissions of data segments

children.help: Set maximum number of retransmissions of SYN segments.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_SYNMAXRTX
children.title: Maximum number of retransmissions of SYN segments

children.help:
Set maximum segment size for TCP transmission.

Can be set lower to save RAM, the default value 1460(ipv4)/1440(ipv6) will give best throughput.
IPv4 TCP_MSS Range: 576 <= TCP_MSS <= 1460
IPv6 TCP_MSS Range: 1220<= TCP_MSS <= 1440
children.name: LWIP_TCP_MSS
children.title: Maximum Segment Size (MSS)

children.help:
Set TCP timer interval in milliseconds.

Can be used to speed connections on bad networks.
A lower value will redeliver unacked packets faster.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_TMR_INTERVAL
children.title: TCP timer interval(ms)

children.help: Set maximum segment lifetime in milliseconds.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_MSL
children.title: Maximum segment lifetime (MSL)

children.help: Set maximum segment lifetime in milliseconds.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_FIN_WAIT_TIMEOUT
children.title: Maximum FIN segment lifetime

children.help:
Set default send buffer size for new TCP sockets.

Per-socket send buffer size can be changed at runtime
with lwip_setsockopt(s, TCP_SNDBUF, ...).

This value must be at least 2x the MSS size, and the default
is 4x the default MSS size.

Setting a smaller default SNDBUF size can save some RAM, but
will decrease performance.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_SND_BUF_DEFAULT
children.title: Default send buffer size

children.help:
Set default TCP receive window size for new TCP sockets.

Per-socket receive window size can be changed at runtime
with lwip_setsockopt(s, TCP_WINDOW, ...).

Setting a smaller default receive window size can save some RAM,
but will significantly decrease performance.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_WND_DEFAULT
children.title: Default receive window size

children.help:
Set TCP receive mail box size. Generally bigger value means higher throughput
but more memory. The recommended value is: LWIP_TCP_WND_DEFAULT/TCP_MSS + 2, e.g. if
LWIP_TCP_WND_DEFAULT=14360, TCP_MSS=1436, then the recommended receive mail box size is
(14360/1436 + 2) = 12.

TCP receive mail box is a per socket mail box, when the application receives packets
from TCP socket, LWIP core firstly posts the packets to TCP receive mail box and the
application then fetches the packets from mail box. It means LWIP can caches maximum
LWIP_TCP_RECCVMBOX_SIZE packets for each TCP socket, so the maximum possible cached TCP packets
for all TCP sockets is LWIP_TCP_RECCVMBOX_SIZE multiples the maximum TCP socket number. In other
words, the bigger LWIP_TCP_RECVMBOX_SIZE means more memory.
On the other hand, if the receive mail box is too small, the mail box may be full. If the
mail box is full, the LWIP drops the packets. So generally we need to make sure the TCP
receive mail box is big enough to avoid packet drop between LWIP core and application.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_RECVMBOX_SIZE
children.title: Default TCP receive mail box size

children.help:
Set TCP accept mail box size. Generally bigger value means supporting larger backlogs
but more memory. The recommended value is 6, but applications can set it to a lower value
if listening servers are meant to have a smaller backlog.

TCP accept mail box is a per socket mail box, when the application listens for connections
with a given listening TCP socket. If the mailbox is full, LWIP will send a RST packet and
the client will fail to connect.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_ACCEPTMBOX_SIZE
children.title: Default TCP accept mail box size

children.help: The timeout value is TCP_OOSEQ_TIMEOUT * RTO.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_OOSEQ_TIMEOUT
children.title: Timeout for each pbuf queued in TCP OOSEQ, in RTOs.

children.help:
If LWIP_TCP_OOSEQ_MAX_PBUFS = 0, TCP will not control the number of OOSEQ pbufs.

In a poor network environment, many out-of-order tcp pbufs will be received.
These out-of-order pbufs will be cached in the TCP out-of-order queue which will
cause Wi-Fi/Ethernet fail to release RX buffer in time.
It is possible that all RX buffers for MAC layer are used by OOSEQ.

Control the number of out-of-order pbufs to ensure
that the MAC layer has enough RX buffer to receive packets.

In the Wi-Fi scenario, recommended OOSEQ PBUFS Range:
0 <= TCP_OOSEQ_MAX_PBUFS <= CONFIG_ESP_WIFI_DYNAMIC_RX_BUFFER_NUM/(MAX_TCP_NUMBER + 1)

In the Ethernet scenario,recommended Ethernet OOSEQ PBUFS Range:
0 <= TCP_OOSEQ_MAX_PBUFS <= CONFIG_ETH_DMA_RX_BUFFER_NUM/(MAX_TCP_NUMBER + 1)

Within the recommended value range, the larger the value, the better the performance.

MAX_TCP_NUMBER represent Maximum number of TCP connections in Wi-Fi(STA+SoftAP) and Ethernet scenario.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_OOSEQ_MAX_PBUFS
children.title: The maximum number of pbufs queued on OOSEQ per pcb

children.help: TCP will support sending selective acknowledgements (SACKs).
children.name: LWIP_TCP_SACK_OUT
children.title: Support sending selective acknowledgements

children.help:
Queue incoming out-of-order segments for later use.

Disable this option to save some RAM during TCP sessions, at the expense
of increased retransmissions if segments arrive out of order.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_QUEUE_OOSEQ
children.title: Queue incoming out-of-order segments

children.help:
Allows enabling "oversize" allocation of TCP transmission pbufs ahead of time,
which can reduce the length of pbuf chains used for transmission.

This will not make a difference to sockets where Nagle's algorithm
is disabled.

Default value of MSS is fine for most applications, 25% MSS may save
some RAM when only transmitting small amounts of data. Disabled will
have worst performance and fragmentation characteristics, but uses
least RAM overall.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_OVERSIZE
children.title: Pre-allocate transmit PBUF size

children.help: Enable this feature to support TCP window scaling.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_RCV_SCALE
children.title: Set TCP receiving window scaling factor

children.help: Enable this feature to support TCP window scaling.
children.name: LWIP_WND_SCALE
children.title: Support TCP window scale

children.help:
Set default TCP rto time for a reasonable initial rto.
In bad network environment, recommend set value of rto time to 1500.
children.name: LWIP_TCP_RTO_TIME
children.title: Default TCP rto time

children.help:
The maximum number of active UDP "connections" (ie
UDP sockets sending/receiving data).
The practical maximum limit is determined by available
heap memory at runtime.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_UDP_PCBS
children.title: Maximum active UDP control blocks

children.help:
Set UDP receive mail box size. The recommended value is 6.

UDP receive mail box is a per socket mail box, when the application receives packets
from UDP socket, LWIP core firstly posts the packets to UDP receive mail box and the
application then fetches the packets from mail box. It means LWIP can caches maximum
UDP_RECCVMBOX_SIZE packets for each UDP socket, so the maximum possible cached UDP packets
for all UDP sockets is UDP_RECCVMBOX_SIZE multiples the maximum UDP socket number. In other
words, the bigger UDP_RECVMBOX_SIZE means more memory.
On the other hand, if the receive mail box is too small, the mail box may be full. If the
mail box is full, the LWIP drops the packets. So generally we need to make sure the UDP
receive mail box is big enough to avoid packet drop between LWIP core and application.
children.name: LWIP_UDP_RECVMBOX_SIZE
children.title: Default UDP receive mail box size

children.help: Enable checksum checking for received IP messages
children.name: LWIP_CHECKSUM_CHECK_IP
children.title: Enable LWIP IP checksums

children.help: Enable checksum checking for received UDP messages
children.name: LWIP_CHECKSUM_CHECK_UDP
children.title: Enable LWIP UDP checksums

children.help: Enable checksum checking for received ICMP messages
children.name: LWIP_CHECKSUM_CHECK_ICMP
children.title: Enable LWIP ICMP checksums

children.help:
Configure TCP/IP task stack size, used by LWIP to process multi-threaded TCP/IP operations.
Setting this stack too small will result in stack overflow crashes.
children.name: LWIP_TCPIP_TASK_STACK_SIZE
children.title: TCP/IP Task Stack Size

children.help:
Allows setting LwIP tasks affinity, i.e. whether the task is pinned to
CPU0, pinned to CPU1, or allowed to run on any CPU.
Currently this applies to "TCP/IP" task and "Ping" task.
children.name: LWIP_TCPIP_TASK_AFFINITY
children.title: TCP/IP task affinity

children.help: Config max number of IPv6 packets to queue during MAC resolution.
children.name: LWIP_IPV6_MEMP_NUM_ND6_QUEUE
children.title: Max number of IPv6 packets to queue during MAC resolution

children.help: Config max number of entries in IPv6 neighbor cache
children.name: LWIP_IPV6_ND6_NUM_NEIGHBORS
children.title: Max number of entries in IPv6 neighbor cache

children.help: Maximum number of entries in IPv6 on-link prefixes cache
children.name: LWIP_IPV6_ND6_NUM_PREFIXES
children.title: Max number of entries in IPv6 on-link prefixes cache

children.help: Maximum number of entries in IPv6 default routers cache
children.name: LWIP_IPV6_ND6_NUM_ROUTERS
children.title: Max number of entries in IPv6 default routers cache

children.help: Maximum number of entries in IPv6 destinations cache
children.name: LWIP_IPV6_ND6_NUM_DESTINATIONS
children.title: Max number of entries in IPv6 destinations cache

children.help:
Enable IPCP protocol in PPP negotiations, which assigns IPv4 addresses to the PPP client,
as well as IPv4 DNS servers.
You can disable this if your modem supports IPv6 only.
children.name: LWIP_PPP_ENABLE_IPV4
children.title: Enable IPV4 support for PPP connections (IPCP)

children.help:
Enable IPV6 support in PPP for the local link between the DTE (processor) and DCE (modem).
There are some modems which do not support the IPV6 addressing in the local link.
If they are requested for IPV6CP negotiation, they may time out.
This would in turn fail the configuration for the whole link.
If your modem is not responding correctly to PPP Phase Network, try to disable IPV6 support.
children.name: LWIP_PPP_ENABLE_IPV6
children.title: Enable IPV6 support for PPP connections (IPV6CP)

children.help: Enable to set a callback which is called on change of the internal PPP state machine.
children.name: LWIP_PPP_NOTIFY_PHASE_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable Notify Phase Callback

children.help: Enable Password Authentication Protocol (PAP) support
children.name: LWIP_PPP_PAP_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable PAP support

children.help: Enable Challenge Handshake Authentication Protocol (CHAP) support
children.name: LWIP_PPP_CHAP_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable CHAP support

children.help: Enable Microsoft version of the Challenge-Handshake Authentication Protocol (MSCHAP) support
children.name: LWIP_PPP_MSCHAP_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable MSCHAP support

children.help: Enable Microsoft Point-to-Point Encryption (MPPE) support
children.name: LWIP_PPP_MPPE_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable MPPE support

children.help: Enable to use PPP server
children.name: LWIP_PPP_SERVER_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable PPP server support

children.help:
Enable support for VJ header compression.
Please disable this if you're using NAPT on PPP interface,
since the compressed IP header might not be correctly interpreted
in NAT causing the compressed packet to be dropped.
children.name: LWIP_PPP_VJ_HEADER_COMPRESSION
children.title: Enable VJ IP Header compression

children.help: Interval in seconds between keepalive LCP echo requests, 0 to disable.
children.name: LWIP_LCP_ECHOINTERVAL
children.title: Echo interval (s)

children.help: Number of consecutive unanswered echo requests before failure is indicated.
children.name: LWIP_LCP_MAXECHOFAILS
children.title: Maximum echo failures

children.help: Enable LCP echo keepalive requests
children.name: LWIP_ENABLE_LCP_ECHO
children.title: Enable LCP ECHO

children.help: Enable PPP debug log output
children.name: LWIP_PPP_DEBUG_ON
children.title: Enable PPP debug log output

children.help:
This option uses mbedTLS crypto functions (instead of internal PolarSSL
implementation) for PPP authentication modes (PAP, CHAP, etc.).
You can use this option to address symbol duplication issues, since
the internal functions are not namespaced (e.g. md5_init()).
children.name: LWIP_USE_EXTERNAL_MBEDTLS
children.title: Use mbedTLS instead of internal polarSSL

children.help: Enable PPP stack. Now only PPP over serial is possible.
children.name: LWIP_PPP_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable PPP support

children.help: Enable SLIP debug log output
children.name: LWIP_SLIP_DEBUG_ON
children.title: Enable SLIP debug log output

children.help:
Enable SLIP stack. Now only SLIP over serial is possible.

SLIP over serial support is experimental and unsupported.
children.name: LWIP_SLIP_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable SLIP support (new/experimental)

children.help: Enable ICMP module for check network stability
children.name: LWIP_ICMP
children.title: ICMP: Enable ICMP

children.help:
The maximum number of simultaneously active LWIP
RAW protocol control blocks. The practical maximum
limit is determined by available heap memory at runtime.
children.name: LWIP_MAX_RAW_PCBS
children.title: Maximum LWIP RAW PCBs

children.help:
Set maximum number of NTP servers used by LwIP SNTP module.
First argument of sntp_setserver/sntp_setservername functions
is limited to this value.
children.name: LWIP_SNTP_MAX_SERVERS
children.title: Maximum number of NTP servers

children.help:
Set maximum number of NTP servers acquired via DHCP-offer.
Should be less or equal to "Maximum number of NTP servers", any extra servers would be just ignored.
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_MAX_NTP_SERVERS
children.title: Maximum number of NTP servers acquired via DHCP

children.help:
If enabled, LWIP will add 'NTP' to Parameter-Request Option sent via DHCP-request.
DHCP server might reply with an NTP server address in option 42.
SNTP callback for such replies should be set accordingly (see sntp_servermode_dhcp() func.)
children.name: LWIP_DHCP_GET_NTP_SRV
children.title: Request NTP servers from DHCP

children.help:
This option allows you to set the time update period via SNTP.
Default is 1 hour. Must not be below 15 seconds by specification.
(SNTPv4 RFC 4330 enforces a minimum update time of 15 seconds).
children.name: LWIP_SNTP_UPDATE_DELAY
children.title: Request interval to update time (ms)

children.help:
RFC 4330 recommends a startup delay before sending the initial request.
LWIP calculates this delay to a random number of milliseconds between 0 and this value.
children.name: LWIP_SNTP_MAXIMUM_STARTUP_DELAY
children.title: Maximum startup delay (ms)

children.help:
It is recommended (RFC 4330) to delay the initial request after by a random timeout from 1 to 5 minutes
to reduce potential load of NTP servers after simultaneous power-up of many devices.
This option disables this initial delay. Please use this option with care, it could improve
a single device responsiveness but might cause peaks on the network after reset.
Another option to address responsiveness of devices while using the initial random delay
is to adjust LWIP_SNTP_MAXIMUM_STARTUP_DELAY.
children.name: LWIP_SNTP_STARTUP_DELAY
children.title: Enable SNTP startup delay

children.help: Maximum number of IP addresses that can be returned by DNS queries for a single host.
children.name: LWIP_DNS_MAX_HOST_IP
children.title: Maximum number of IP addresses per host

children.help:
Set maximum number of DNS servers.
If fallback DNS servers are supported,
the number of DNS servers needs to be greater than or equal to 3.
children.name: LWIP_DNS_MAX_SERVERS
children.title: Maximum number of DNS servers

children.help: This option allows you to config dns fallback server address.
children.name: LWIP_FALLBACK_DNS_SERVER_ADDRESS
children.title: DNS fallback server address

children.help: Enable this feature to support DNS fallback server.
children.name: LWIP_FALLBACK_DNS_SERVER_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable DNS fallback server support

children.help:
This option allows collecting DNS server settings per netif using
configurable callback function.
It's typically used with CONFIG_ESP_NETIF_SET_DNS_PER_DEFAULT_NETIF
which configures a callback to collect the DNS info on esp_netif layer.
children.name: LWIP_DNS_SETSERVER_WITH_NETIF
children.title: Enable DNS server settings with netif

children.help: Set maximum number of ports a bridge can consists of.
children.name: LWIP_BRIDGEIF_MAX_PORTS
children.title: Maximum number of bridge ports

children.help:
Enable this option keeps LWIP assertion checks enabled.
It is recommended to keep this option enabled.

If asserts are disabled for the entire project, they are also disabled
for LWIP and this option is ignored.
children.name: LWIP_ESP_LWIP_ASSERT
children.title: Enable LWIP ASSERT checks

children.help:
Enables to define a TCP ISN hook to randomize initial sequence
number in TCP connection.
The default TCP ISN algorithm used in IDF (standardized in RFC 6528)
produces ISN by combining an MD5 of the new TCP id and a stable
secret with the current time.
This is because the lwIP implementation (`tcp_next_iss`) is not
very strong, as it does not take into consideration any platform
specific entropy source.

Set to LWIP_HOOK_TCP_ISN_CUSTOM to provide custom implementation.
Set to LWIP_HOOK_TCP_ISN_NONE to use lwIP implementation.
children.name: LWIP_HOOK_TCP_ISN
children.title: TCP ISN Hook

children.help:
Enables custom IPv6 route hook.
Setting this to "default" provides weak implementation
stub that could be overwritten in application code.
Setting this to "custom" provides hook's declaration
only and expects the application to implement it.
children.name: LWIP_HOOK_IP6_ROUTE
children.title: IPv6 route Hook

children.help:
Enables custom IPv6 route hook.
Setting this to "default" provides weak implementation
stub that could be overwritten in application code.
Setting this to "custom" provides hook's declaration
only and expects the application to implement it.
children.name: LWIP_HOOK_ND6_GET_GW
children.title: IPv6 get gateway Hook

children.help:
Enables custom IPv6 source address selection.
Setting this to "default" provides weak implementation
stub that could be overwritten in application code.
Setting this to "custom" provides hook's declaration
only and expects the application to implement it.
children.name: LWIP_HOOK_IP6_SELECT_SRC_ADDR
children.title: IPv6 source address selection Hook

children.help:
Enables custom DNS resolve hook (without callback).
Setting this to "default" provides weak implementation
stub that could be overwritten in application code.
Setting this to "custom" provides hook's declaration
only and expects the application to implement it.
children.name: LWIP_HOOK_NETCONN_EXTERNAL_RESOLVE
children.title: Netconn external resolve Hook

children.help:
